awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  Collaborative Research:  Correspondence Discovery in Disparate Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
In many important data mining applications, the input networks may be collected from different sources, at different times, at different granularities, with partially or completely different sets of nodes, and thus create the disparity issue. The network correspondence problem, which aims to find the node or network alignment across different input networks, is a vital stepping stone behind a variety of high-impact applications. For example, in bioinformatics, network correspondence is often the very first step toward discovering which diseases are related to which proteins in order to help design new drugs or re-purpose the existing ones; in brain-informatics, it can help detect which brain wirings are correlated with certain diseases and personality traits;  in management, finding the correspondence between different team networks is often the key to characterize high-performing vs. dysfunctional teams within an enterprise. The vast majority, with only very few exceptions, of the existing work on network correspondence focuses on pairwise alignment for static and homogeneous (i.e., uni-partite) graphs, although many emerging applications often produce multiple (more than two), dynamic and heterogeneous graphs. The overall goal of this project is to discover correspondence in disparate networks in order to enable collective mining of them.  

This project will investigate three main research tasks, which incorporate constraints from realistic scenarios and applications: (1) Linkage of heterogeneous networks with multiple types of nodes and edges, (2) Linkage of dynamic networks, and (3) Collective network linkage, as opposed to pairwise comparison and alignment of networks. Accurate and efficient linkage of different types of networks will enable the applications of the existing graph mining tools to a collection of disparate networks, and lead to new insights in a variety of important application domains. This project will advance the state-of-the-art techniques on mining disparate networks in multiple dimensions, including its generality, applicability, effectiveness, and scalability. The algorithms developed from this project will be applicable to a wide range of high-impact domains, such as social sciences, brain-informatics, and bioinformatics. The research outcomes will be disseminated by publications, conference tutorials, open-source software, as well as potential tech transfer.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.inst_name: Regents of the University of Michigan - Ann Arbor
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN

por.por_cntn:
In many data mining applications, the input networks may be collected from different sources, at different times, at different granularities, with partially or completely different sets of nodes, and thus create a disparity issue. The network correspondence problem, which aims to find the node or network alignment across different input networks, is a vital stepping stone behind a variety of high-impact applications. For example, in bioinformatics, network correspondence is often the very first step toward discovering which diseases are related to which proteins in order to help design new drugs or re-purpose the existing ones; in brain-informatics, it can help detect which brain wirings are correlated with certain diseases and personality traits; in management, finding the correspondence between different team networks is often the key to characterize high-performing vs. dysfunctional teams. The vast majority of the existing work on network correspondence (with only very few exceptions) focuses on pairwise alignment for static and homogeneous graphs, although many emerging applications often produce multiple, dynamic and heterogeneous graphs.

The overall goal of this project is to discover correspondence in disparate networks in order to enable collective mining of them. During the course of the project, we developed several new alignment methods for attributed networks that (1) outperform the prior methods in terms of the alignment accuracy and (2) scale linearly, or at least subquadratically, with respect to the input network size in the following three aspects. Specifically, the project introduced a new, versatile framework that leverages the power of automatically learned, attribute-aware node representations to match nodes across different graphs---this is the first investigation of the capabilities of representation learning in complex, multi-network tasks. Besides, the project led to an efficient and intuitive hash-based framework for aligning multiple large networks simultaneously, when initial seed matchings are not available. The outputs of these methods can be treated as the final node alignments, or can be used as inputs of optimization formulations that are traditionally applied to network alignment problems.

This project educated and trained multiple graduate and undergraduate students. The research outcomes of the graduate students have become integral parts of their theses. A graduate student involved in this project received an NSF 2018 Graduate Research (GRFP) fellowship, as well as Rackham Dean's and Named PhD fellowship. The project informed the general public in the form of special issues, workshops (KDD 2017-2018), class projects, partnerships with the city of Detroit, and invited talks by the PIs at conferences, and academic or industrial seminars. The associated software prototypes, papers, and presentations from this project have been made publicly available via the project website.

 

 


Last Modified: 10/27/2018
Modified by: Danai Koutra
